comments:
Engineers and scientists create and lead great companies, hiring managers when
and where needed to help execute their vision. Designed expressly for students having a
keen interest in technological innovation, this course investigates the roles of inventors
and founders in successful technology ventures. Through case studies and guest
speakers, we introduce the knowledge and skills needed to recognize and seize a hightech
entrepreneurial opportunity - be it a product or service - and then successfully launch
a startup or spin-off company. The course studies key areas of intellectual property, its
protection and strategic value; opportunity analysis and concept testing; shaping
technology driven inventions into customer-driven products; constructing defensible
competitive strategies; acquiring resources in the form of capital, people and strategic
partners; and the founder's leadership role in an emerging high-tech company.
Throughout the course emphasis is placed on decisions faced by founders, and on the
sequential risks and determinants of success in the early growth phase of a technology
venture. The course is designed for, but not restricted to, students of engineering and
applied science and assumes no prior business education.
The general consensus from the undergrads and graduate students who completed
this course was that it was very helpful, interesting and useful. Students felt that it was
easy to fall behind because there is much reading and writing involved in the class. Some
expressed disappointment in the fact that the professor chose outdated case studies and
felt that most of the class time was done to re-hash the case studies, feeling that this was a
waste of time.
There were mixed feelings about this professor. Most of the students thought that
the professor was very good: "He is a brilliant Instructor and I learned so much more than
thought I would learn." Professor Babin was approachable for questions and he chose
case studies with useful information. However, the professor was not forgiving when
some students had to miss class for job interviews. Some students wished that the
professor would update the case studies integrated in the class discussions.
There was no midterm or project in this class. For this reason, much of your
grade is heavily based on participation in class discussion and quizzes. Missing a class is
prohibited due to the fact that discussion is a large component of the class. Nevertheless,
many students would agree that they learned a lot in this class, the information was very
useful, and that this was a great class.

This course is designed expressly for students having a keen interest in
technological innovation, as students investigate the roles of inventors and founders in
successful technology ventures. Through case studies and guest speakers, the knowledge
and skills needed to recognize and seize a high-tech entrepreneurial opportunity - be it a
product or service – are introduced and then used to successfully launch a startup or spinoff
company. The course studies key areas of intellectual property, its protection and
strategic value, opportunity analysis, concept testing, shaping technology driven
inventions into customer-driven products, constructing defensible competitive strategies,
acquiring resources in the form of capital, people and strategic partners, and the founder's
leadership role in an emerging high-tech company. Throughout the course emphasis is
placed on decisions faced by founders, and on the sequential risks and determinants of
success in the early growth phase of a technology venture. The course is designed for, but
not restricted to, students of engineering and applied science and assumes no prior
business education.
The majority of the students felt that it was one of the “best engineering courses”
given at Penn. They felt that the course was extremely “well organized” and that it
provided a lot of “valuable knowledge” about entrepreneurship and starting up a
businesses. Students also felt that the material taught in this class would forever directly
apply to their experience in the workforce.
Students were very pleased with Professor Cassel, describing him as “very nice
and helpful.”
This course required a lot of work and time commitment. There is also a lot of
“busy work” throughout the semester. In addition, some of the students felt that the
grading was rather tough. However, students did feel that the class was “worth the
investment.” Prerequisites for this course are simply a junior, senior, or graduate level
standing.
